column2: 34 parameters from Katie's paper (mostly hydrology, SP mode):
column4: Location of parameter: PFT params file (P), Namelist (N), or Hard coded (H)

column3: Ratio of displacement height to canopy top height
column15: Zeng and Wang (2007), Raupach (1994), Shaw and Pereira (1982)
column16: Using one range of values for all PFT since there is little variation built into the default model values.

column3: Characteristic dimension of leaves in the direction of wind flow
column15: Kattge et al. (2011), Prentice et al. (2011), Campbell and Norman (1998), Parkhurst et al. (1968)

column3: Allocation parameter: new fine root C per new leaf C
column15: Atkin et al. (2015), Litton et al. (2007), Iversen et al. (2015), Mokany et al. (2006), Malhi et al. (2011)
column16: Some evidence for larger than 10% variation (Atkin et al. 2015), but values are PFT-dependent.

column15: Bonan et al. (2014), Chuang et al. (2006), Sperry et al. (1998), Sperry and Love (2015), Williams et al (1996), Kennedy et al. (2019)
column16: Has the capability to vary w/ PFT and segment: sunlit, shaded, xylem, root. I did not include any of that variation in my perturbations. In general, unclear how to set min/max values, so I set the ranges to include at least 1 order of magnitude difference.

column15: Bonan et al. (2014), Chuang et al. (2006), Sperry et al. (1998), Sperry and Love (2015), Williams et al (1996), Kennedy et al. (2019)
column16: How does this parameter differ from the "root" segment of kmax? Similar to kmax, ranges include at least 1 order of magnitude difference.

column3: Water potential at 50% loss of conductance
column15: Kennedy et al. (2019), Males and Griffiths (2017)
column16: Has the capability to vary w/ PFT and segment: sunlit, shaded, xylem, root.

column3: Rooting beta parameter, for C and N vertical discretization
column15: Jackson et al. (1996)
column16:
2 variants for this variable: carbon and water uptake
Have to be careful that the max values don't go over 1 (physically unreasonable).
Alternate approach (from Daniel) could be to map this parameter to rooting depth and perturb that quantity intsead. Could be easier to find physically reasonable ranges for each PFT.

column3: Ratio of momentum roughness length to canopy top height
column15: Zeng and Wang (2007), Raupach (1994), Shaw and Pereira (1982)

column3: Scalar multiplier for base flow rate
column15: Expert judgement
column16: SoilHydrologyMod.F90 defines this parameter as 0.01 (line 40) which is different from the namelist value of 0.001. I tested to see if perturbing the namelist value does anything (otherwise source code is overriding namelist value). UPDATE: perturbation does change outputs, namelist is not overriden

column3: Maximum fraction of leaf that may be wet prior to drip occuring
column15: Expert judgement
column16: Parameter range suggested by Sean; suggested to be widened by Dave. Tech note suggests fwet cannot be greater than or equal to 1, but namelist sets this parameter at 0.05 in the default.

column15: Expert judgement
column16: Parameter range suggested by Sean; suggested to be narrowed by Dave. Since max range value = default, only run one simulation here and use control simulation as max.

column5: [const in rous and s_y max definitions]
column15: Niu et al. (2007)
column16:
Subroutines: WaterTable, Drainage, PerchedLateralFlow, LateralFlowPowerLaw
WaterTable and Drainage are only called if use_aquifer_layer=True and it is false if lower_boundary_condition=2 (bc_zero_flux) which is the CLM5 default.
PerchedLateralFlow and LateralFlowPowerLaw appear to be called in HydrologyDrainage which is called in clm_driver. Where is this described in the tech note? Minimum value could be lower depending on combination of soil properties and water table depth (calculations done separately).

column3: Decay factor for fractional saturated area
column8:
set in: SoilHydrologyMod.F90 (line 213)
called in: SoilHydrologyMod.F90 (lines 231, 239, 243)
column15: Niu et al. (2005), Hou et al. (2012), Fan and Miguez-Macho (2011), Fan et al. (2013)
column16:
Related to surface runoff (subroutine SurfaceRunoff). Given recharge from other papers, can invert for fff parameter which helps give bounds for sensitivity.
Two instances are not used if use_vichydro=True (default is OFF)
Third instance is used to calculate fsat if frost_table > zwt_perched

column3: Maximum storage of liquid water on leaf surface
column8:
set in: CanopyStateType.F90 (line 518)
called in: CanopyHydrologyMod.F90 (lines 321, 721, 726)
column15: Rutter et al. (1971), Rutter (1975), Rutter et al. (1975), Rutter and Morton (1977), Deardorff (1978), Massman (1980), Dickinson (1984), Noilhan and Planton (1989), Dickinson et al. (1993), Keim et al. (2006)
column16:
Subroutines: CanopyHydrology, FracWet
Ideally want this parameter to vary with PFT, as it is clearly different for different veg types (e.g. needle versus broadleaf). Maybe want something that is described "per LAI/SAI" so you can multiply by LAI. There are issues with observational values including bark wetting, fraction of precip that doesn't even fall on leaves, etc.

column3: Maximum storage of snow on leaf surface
column5:
(1) [first const in snocanmx eqn]
(2) [first 2 consts in fcansnow eqn]
column15: Pomeroy et al. (1998), Hedstrom and Pomeroy (1998), Storck et al. (2002)
column16:
Defined in source code as 60 * dewmx = 60 * 0.1 = 6, and later in fcansno equation with similar arithmetic.
Pomeroy et al. (1998) write that this parameter is often underestimated in LSMs and should be calculated with a process-based snow interception model (e.g., Hedstrom and Pomeroy, 1998)

column15: Swenson and Lawrence (2014), van de Griend and Owe (1994), Goss and Madliger (2007), Smits et al. (2012)
column16:
Parameter specifying the length scale of max DSL (dry surface layer) thickness
Requires soil_resis_method = sl_14 which it is by default (as opposed to leepielke_1992)

column3: Fraction of saturated soil for moisture value at which DSL initiates
column15: Swenson and Lawrence (2014)
column16: Called "K" in Swenson and Lawrence (2014). Is used to calculate Î¸_init (as it's called in the tech note) when multiplied by the porosity. Î¸_init is the moisture value at which DSL initiates.

column3: Accumulation constant for fractional snow covered area
column8:
set in: CanopyHydrologyMod.F90 (line 520)
used in: CanopyHydrologyMod.F90 (lines 538, 578)
column15: Swenson and Lawrence (2012)
column16: Chosen value represents "plausible lower limit" (Swenson and Lawrence 2012)

column3: Parameter controlling shape of snow covered area
column8:
set in: initVerticalMod.F90 (line 721)
used in: SnowHydrologyMod.F90 (line 722)
CanopyHydrologyMod.F90 (lines 532, 543, 583)
column15: Swenson and Lawrence (2012)
column16:
N_melt ranges [0.25,8] (Swenson and Lawrence, 2012), 200 comes from tuning N_melt given sd of topography (sigma_topo) where N_melt = 200/sigma_topo. More information on DEM model from the USGS HYDRO1K 1-km dataset (Verdin and Greenlee, 1996) or http://www6.uniovi.es/usr/feli/Data/info.html
Try 10% perturbation for now, in absense of other information.

column16: Used to calculate Michaelis-Menten constants which inform the Rubisco-limited rate of carboxylation for photosynthesis. The first instance in the Photosynthesis code is for PHS off, the second is for PHS on. Also used in LUNA code.

column15: Bernacchi et al. (2001), Brooks and Farquhar (1985)
column16: Used to calculate the CO2 compensation point which informs the Rubisco- and light-limited rates of carboxylation for photosynthesis. The first instance in the code is for PHS off, the second is for PHS on. Definition in code seems to depend on partial pressure of oxygen in air, not atmospheric pressure (?).

column16: Specific activity of rubisco at 25Â°C, varies with temperature and some older papers calculate values at 30Â°C. CLM sensitivity range calculated using the Q10 value and formula from Woodrow and Berry (1988). The first instance in the code is for PHS off, the second is for PHS on.
